Question: How many people live in your household and purchase/prepare food together?
Qualifying_Answers: Any number (1-8+ people) - determines benefit amount and income limits
Disqualifying_Answers: None - household size doesn't disqualify but affects eligibility calculations
Notes: Larger households have higher income limits. Must include all people who live together and purchase/prepare food together, including non-relatives.

Question: What is your household's total monthly gross income (before taxes and deductions)?
Qualifying_Answers: <=200% FPL for most households; <=165% FPL if elderly/disabled member; <=130% FPL for some categories
Disqualifying_Answers: Income exceeding applicable Federal Poverty Level percentage for household size
Notes: 2025 FPL: $1,580/month (1 person), $2,137/month (2 people). Some deductions may apply. Students may have different limits.

Question: Does your household include anyone who is 60+ years old or has a disability?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes (qualifies for 200% FPL limit) OR No (qualifies for 165% FPL limit)
Disqualifying_Answers: None - both answers can qualify, just different income limits apply
Notes: Elderly/disabled households get higher income limits and may be exempt from certain requirements.

Question: Are you a resident of California?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - must be California resident
Disqualifying_Answers: No - not a California resident
Notes: Must apply in county where you live. Temporary absence doesn't disqualify if you intend to return.

Question: What is your citizenship/immigration status?
Qualifying_Answers: U.S. citizen OR qualified non-citizen (LPR, refugee, asylee, certain others)
Disqualifying_Answers: Undocumented immigrants, temporary visitors, students on F-1 visas
Notes: Mixed-status households can apply for eligible members. Some non-citizens have 5-year waiting period.

Question: Are you between ages 18-54, able-bodied, and without dependents (ABAWD)?
Qualifying_Answers: No (not ABAWD) OR Yes but working 20+ hours/week OR Yes with exemption
Disqualifying_Answers: Yes and not working 20+ hours/week and no exemption
Notes: ABAWDs limited to 3 months in 36-month period unless working/training. Exemptions include disability, pregnancy, caring for child under 6.

Question: Are you a student enrolled at least half-time in college (ages 18-49)?
Qualifying_Answers: No (not a student) OR Yes with qualifying exemption (work 20+ hrs, caring for child under 6, receiving TANF, etc.)
Disqualifying_Answers: Yes, student without qualifying exemption
Notes: Student exemptions include: work-study, caring for dependent under 6, single parent with child under 12, receiving TANF.

Question: Do you have less than $100 in liquid resources?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes (may qualify for expedited service) OR No but meet other criteria
Disqualifying_Answers: Excessive liquid resources (varies by household type)
Notes: Most households have no asset limits. Elderly/disabled households: $4,250 limit. Expedited service if <$100 and very low income.

Question: What is your household's total monthly gross income (before taxes and deductions)?
Qualifying_Answers: <=138% FPL (adults) OR <=266% FPL (children/pregnant women)
Disqualifying_Answers: Income exceeding applicable FPL percentage for category
Notes: Different pathways: MAGI (most adults/children), non-MAGI (elderly/disabled). Pregnant women eligible up to 213% FPL.

Question: What is your age?
Qualifying_Answers: Any age - different pathways available
Disqualifying_Answers: None - age determines pathway, not eligibility
Notes: Children (0-18), Adults (19-64), Elderly (65+) have different income limits and requirements.

Question: Are you currently pregnant?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes (higher income limits apply) OR No (standard limits apply)
Disqualifying_Answers: None - pregnancy status affects income limits but doesn't disqualify
Notes: Pregnant women eligible up to 213% FPL. Coverage continues through pregnancy and 60 days postpartum.

Question: Do you have a disability as defined by Social Security Administration?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes (may qualify under disability pathway) OR No (may qualify under other pathways)
Disqualifying_Answers: None - disability status opens additional pathways
Notes: Disabled individuals may qualify regardless of age through SSI or other disability pathways.

Question: Do you currently receive SSI, CalFresh, or CalWorks?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - automatically income-eligible for Medi-Cal
Disqualifying_Answers: None - if 'No', may still qualify through income or other pathways
Notes: Categorical eligibility - receiving these benefits automatically qualifies for Medi-Cal without separate income test.

Question: What is your citizenship/immigration status?
Qualifying_Answers: U.S. citizen OR qualified non-citizen
Disqualifying_Answers: Undocumented immigrants (except emergency services)
Notes: Emergency Medi-Cal available for undocumented immigrants. Some non-citizens subject to 5-year waiting period.

Question: Are you a California resident?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - California resident
Disqualifying_Answers: No - not a California resident
Notes: Must intend to reside in California. Temporary absence doesn't disqualify if planning to return.

Question: Are you 65 or older, blind, or disabled?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - at least one: Age 65+, blind (specific vision criteria), or disabled (unable to work)
Disqualifying_Answers: No - under 65, not blind, and not disabled
Notes: Must meet SSA definition of disability: unable to engage in substantial gainful activity due to medical condition lasting 12+ months.

Question: What is your monthly income from non-work sources?
Qualifying_Answers: Less than $987/month for individuals, $1,485/month for couples (2025)
Disqualifying_Answers: $987+ monthly for individuals, $1,485+ for couples
Notes: Includes Social Security, pensions, unemployment. First $20/month excluded. Some income may not count.

Question: What is your monthly income from work/self-employment?
Qualifying_Answers: Less than $2,019/month for individuals (includes work incentives)
Disqualifying_Answers: $2,019+ monthly from work
Notes: First $65/month excluded, then 50% of remainder excluded. Student exclusions may apply.

Question: What is the total value of your countable resources?
Qualifying_Answers: Less than $2,000 for individuals, $3,000 for couples
Disqualifying_Answers: $2,000+ for individuals, $3,000+ for couples
Notes: Excludes home, one vehicle, burial funds up to $1,500, household goods, life insurance under $1,500.

Question: Are you married and living with your spouse?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes (couple rates apply) OR No (individual rates apply)
Disqualifying_Answers: None - affects benefit amount and limits, not eligibility
Notes: Couple must both be eligible for SSI to receive couple rate. Otherwise individual rates apply.

Question: What is your citizenship/immigration status?
Qualifying_Answers: U.S. citizen OR qualified non-citizen (LPR before 8/22/96 or meet exceptions)
Disqualifying_Answers: Most non-citizens who arrived after 8/22/96, undocumented immigrants
Notes: Very limited non-citizen eligibility. Refugees/asylees eligible for 7 years, then must meet other criteria.

Question: Do you live in one of the 50 states, DC, or Northern Mariana Islands?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - resident of qualifying location
Disqualifying_Answers: No - living outside the 50 states, DC, or Northern Mariana Islands
Notes: Not available in Puerto Rico, Guam, Virgin Islands. Must be residing in qualifying area to receive benefits.

Question: How many Social Security work credits have you earned?
Qualifying_Answers: Generally 40+ credits (varies by age - younger workers need fewer)
Disqualifying_Answers: Insufficient work credits for age
Notes: Need 1-39 credits depending on age at disability onset. 1 credit = $1,640 in earnings (2025). Maximum 4 credits per year.

Question: How many work credits did you earn in the last 10 years?
Qualifying_Answers: Generally 20+ credits in last 10 years before disability (20/40 rule)
Disqualifying_Answers: Fewer than required recent work credits
Notes: Recent work test varies by age. Workers disabled before 31 need credits for half the years since age 21.

Question: Has your disability lasted or is it expected to last 12 months or more?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - condition lasts/expected to last 12+ months OR is terminal
Disqualifying_Answers: No - condition expected to last less than 12 months
Notes: Must be severe enough to prevent substantial gainful activity. Terminal illnesses qualify immediately.

Question: Are you currently earning more than $1,260 per month from work?
Qualifying_Answers: No - earning less than $1,260/month (2025 SGA limit)
Disqualifying_Answers: Yes - earning $1,260+ monthly (substantial gainful activity)
Notes: $2,190/month limit for blind individuals. Trial work periods and work incentives may apply during initial years.

Question: Does your condition significantly limit your ability to do basic work activities?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - severe impairment affecting basic work functions
Disqualifying_Answers: No - condition doesn't significantly limit work ability
Notes: Basic work activities include walking, sitting, lifting, remembering, following instructions. Must be medically documented.

Question: Are you under full retirement age?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - under full retirement age (66-67 depending on birth year)
Disqualifying_Answers: No - at or over full retirement age
Notes: SSDI automatically converts to retirement benefits at full retirement age. Cannot receive both simultaneously.

Question: Is your household income at or below 50% of area median income?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - at or below 50% AMI (very low income) or 30% AMI (extremely low income)
Disqualifying_Answers: No - income exceeds 50% of area median income
Notes: 75% of vouchers must go to families at/below 30% AMI. Income limits vary by metropolitan area and are updated annually.

Question: How many people are in your household?
Qualifying_Answers: Any size (1+ people) - determines appropriate unit size and income limits
Disqualifying_Answers: None - household size affects calculations but doesn't disqualify
Notes: Larger households have higher income limits. Bedroom size based on household composition and local housing authority policies.

Question: Is the head of household at least 18 years old or legally emancipated minor?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - age 18+ OR legally emancipated minor
Disqualifying_Answers: No - under 18 and not legally emancipated
Notes: Emancipated minors need court documentation. Some programs have special provisions for youth aging out of foster care.

Question: What is your citizenship/immigration status?
Qualifying_Answers: U.S. citizen OR eligible non-citizen as defined by HUD
Disqualifying_Answers: Non-eligible immigration status
Notes: Mixed-status families can apply but only eligible members counted for voucher size. Must provide immigration documentation.

Question: Do you have any disqualifying criminal convictions?
Qualifying_Answers: No disqualifying convictions OR eligible for waiver/rehabilitation consideration
Disqualifying_Answers: Yes - conviction for drug manufacturing/distribution, lifetime sex offender registration, or recent violent crimes
Notes: PHAs have discretion for most crimes except lifetime drug/sex offenses. Background checks required for all adult household members.

Question: Does the head of household have a valid Social Security Number?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - valid SSN for head of household
Disqualifying_Answers: No - no valid SSN for head of household
Notes: All household members over 6 must have or apply for SSN. Mixed-status families may have different requirements.

Question: Do you have dependent children under 18 (or 19 if full-time student)?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - have dependent child(ren) under 18 (or 19 if in school full-time)
Disqualifying_Answers: No - no dependent children in household
Notes: Child must live with parent/caretaker relative. 19-year-olds must be full-time students expected to graduate by age 19.

Question: Is your household's monthly gross income below the state limit?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - gross income below state-set limits (varies by state and family size)
Disqualifying_Answers: No - income exceeds state maximum for family size
Notes: California 2025: roughly $1,000-$1,600/month depending on family size. Varies significantly by state.

Question: Do you have countable assets under state limits?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - assets under $1,000-$2,000 (varies by state)
Disqualifying_Answers: No - assets exceed state limits
Notes: Excludes home, one vehicle, household goods, burial plots. Some states have higher limits or no asset test.

Question: Are you a U.S. citizen or qualified non-citizen who has been in the U.S. for 5+ years?
Qualifying_Answers: U.S. citizen OR qualified non-citizen meeting 5-year requirement OR exempt category
Disqualifying_Answers: Non-citizen not meeting requirements
Notes: 5-year bar applies to most non-citizens. Exceptions for refugees, asylees, veterans, active military families.

Question: Have you received TANF benefits for less than 48 months in your lifetime?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - received TANF for less than 48 months lifetime
Disqualifying_Answers: No - already received 48+ months of TANF benefits
Notes: Federal 60-month limit, but California has 48-month limit. Some states have shorter limits. Hardship exemptions may apply.

Question: Are you able to participate in work activities or have an exemption?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - able to participate in work/training OR qualify for exemption
Disqualifying_Answers: No - unable/unwilling to participate without valid exemption
Notes: Exemptions: caring for child under 12 months, disabled, caring for disabled family member, pregnant (later months).

Question: Are all children ages 6-17 in your household attending school regularly?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - all school-age children attending regularly OR no school-age children
Disqualifying_Answers: No - school-age children not attending school without valid excuse
Notes: Homeschooling acceptable if meets state requirements. Medical/family emergencies may excuse absences.

Question: Are you willing to cooperate with child support enforcement?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - willing to cooperate with child support establishment/collection
Disqualifying_Answers: No - unwilling to cooperate without good cause exemption
Notes: Good cause exemptions for domestic violence, risk to child safety, pending adoption. Must identify other parent if known.

Question: Are you pregnant, breastfeeding, postpartum, or have children under 5?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - pregnant, breastfeeding (up to 1 year), postpartum (up to 6 months), infants, or children under 5
Disqualifying_Answers: No - don't fit any eligible category
Notes: Postpartum women eligible 6 months after birth. Breastfeeding women eligible up to child's 1st birthday.

Question: Is your household income at or below 185% of Federal Poverty Level?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - at or below 185% FPL for household size
Disqualifying_Answers: No - income exceeds 185% FPL
Notes: 2025: $2,915/month (family of 3), $3,523/month (family of 4). Higher than SNAP but lower than some Medicaid categories.

Question: Do you currently receive Medicaid, SNAP, or TANF?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - receiving any of these benefits (automatically income-eligible) OR No but meet income test
Disqualifying_Answers: None - if 'No', must meet income requirements separately
Notes: Categorical eligibility - receiving these benefits means automatic income qualification without separate income verification.

Question: Are you a California resident?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - California resident
Disqualifying_Answers: No - not a California resident
Notes: Must live in California. Temporary absence (vacation, medical care) doesn't disqualify if intending to return.

Question: Do you have a medical or dietary condition putting you at nutritional risk?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - at nutritional risk (medical or dietary-based) as determined by health professional
Disqualifying_Answers: No - not at nutritional risk
Notes: Determined by WIC nutritionist/healthcare provider. Includes medical conditions, dietary deficiencies, failure to thrive.

Question: Is your household income within LIHEAP guidelines for your area?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - income at or below local LIHEAP limits (typically around 60% state median income)
Disqualifying_Answers: No - income exceeds local LIHEAP guidelines
Notes: Guidelines vary by provider and region. Some areas use 200% FPL, others use state median income percentages.

Question: Is the applicant at least 18 years old?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - applicant is 18+ years old
Disqualifying_Answers: No - applicant under 18
Notes: Applicant must be adult household member responsible for energy bills. Emancipated minors may qualify with documentation.

Question: Is your household elderly (60+), disabled, or have children under 6?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - household includes vulnerable members OR No but still may qualify
Disqualifying_Answers: None - priority factor but not required for eligibility
Notes: Priority for limited funds given to households with elderly, disabled, or young children. Others served as funding allows.

Question: Do you pay a high portion of your income for energy costs?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - high energy burden (typically 6%+ of income) OR any burden level
Disqualifying_Answers: None - affects priority but not basic eligibility
Notes: High energy burden increases priority for assistance. Some programs prioritize households spending 10%+ on energy.

Question: Do you have a disconnection notice or energy-related emergency?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - have disconnection notice or energy crisis OR No but qualify for regular assistance
Disqualifying_Answers: None - crisis determines type of assistance, not eligibility
Notes: Crisis assistance available year-round. Regular assistance typically seasonal. Some areas require notice/shutoff for priority.

Question: Do you live in the service area of a LIHEAP provider?
Qualifying_Answers: Yes - live in area served by LIHEAP provider
Disqualifying_Answers: No - live outside any LIHEAP provider service area
Notes: Must apply to provider serving your address. Service areas usually by county or utility territory.
